-KlYdxo8zz92G7yutUUB.content: De keuze bij het zoeken naar een baan is primair tussen hoe leuk het werk is en hoeveel men betaald wordt (natuurlijk ook nog zaken als afstand, gevolgen voor privéleven, werktijden, status etc., al zouden die mogelijk deels on der het voorgaande geschaard kunnen). Traditioneel kan dit worden gezien, en door veel neo-liberalen wordt dit gezien, als een keuze tussen zinnig werk (vertaald in salaris) en leuk werk – een belangrijke en zinnige keuze. Dit is echter een verkeerde manier van kijken om twee redenen. Ten eerste is zinnig werk op zichzelf al beloning – een groot deel van wat leuk is aan werk is het gevoel dat het zinnig is. Ten tweede maakt grootschalig marktfalen (en de onwil om daar tegen op te treden) dat inkomsten zelden een vertaling zijn van maatschappelijke opbrengsten. Door die combinatie is er iets opmerkelijks gebeurd: het nut van het werk is naar de “andere kant” van het dilemma geschoven (de mate waarin het een “leuke” baan is), en mensen twijfelen nu tussen iets zinnigs doen of geld verdienen. Volkomen gebruikelijk willen werknemers bij gebrek aan zin (maatschappelijke verantwoording) in het werk wil salaris (of, denk ik, eigenlijk misschien meer de status die daarbij komt – dan is er tenminste nog een reden om trots te zijn op je werk). De absurde situatie ontstaat dat mensen die het meest zinnige werk doen het minst betaald krijgen; zij krijgen er immers al voldoening van het leveren van een bijdrage voor. Salaris is eerder een beloning voor aan jezelf moeten verkopen dat je niets bijdraagt.

-KlYdxo9P3Y2sszLR4wq.content: • Onderwijs – en de keuzes die we over de inrichting maken – bepaalt onze maatschappij (nu de kul van de kennissamenleving): o Onderwijs functioneert primair als etiketteringsmachine, niet als vaardighedenfabriek.  Er zijn helemaal geen belangrijke vaardigheden te leren, hoger onderwijs is verspilling van tijd. • De behoefte aan vaardigheden is zwaar overschat. Voor 90% van wat er in de samenleving moet gebeuren zijn studenten meer dan “opgeleid” tegen het einde van de middelbare school (of zelfs nog eerder) • Voor de meeste beroepsgroepen (zelfs die op dit moment hoog opgeleiden aantrekken) is het functioneler als studenten gewoon meteen vanaf hun 18e aan de slag gaan: dan hebben ze het rond hun 25e meer in de vingers dan na vijf jaar wetenschappelijke opleiding. In feite is het dus verspilde tijd (als het je alleen om de economie zou gaan). • De rest van de opleiding is alleen maar om leerlingen verder uit te sorteren, niet om belangrijke vaardigheden aan te leren • Het is natuurlijk wel een mooi economisch argument dat voor onderwijs pleit, maar het is voor het grootste gedeelte onzin: laten we investeren in nog meer hoger onderwijs.  Onderwijs (duur van de opleiding / type opleiding) laat wel aan een toekomstige werkgever zien wat je kunt en hoezeer je kunt functioneren in typische Westerse kantooromgevingen. • Gevolg: beleid dat zich richt op een groter percentage “hoogopgeleiden” is totaal zinloos, het devalueert alleen bestaande diploma’s en we moeten op zoek naar nog hogere opleidingen (nu ook een promotie, een exacte studie ipv sociale wetenschap, honours programma etc.). Als het je alleen om de economie gaat “verspillen” we nog meer tijd. • Voorbeeld: voor een baan in de consultancy kun je het beste natuurkunde of wiskunde gestudeerd hebben: de ultieme sociale verspilling van middelen. o De arbeidsplaatsen in de samenleving zijn voor een groot gedeelte gevormd door ons onderwijsstelsel in plaats van andersom.  Het grootste gedeelte van onze samenleving zetten we in het arbeidsproces in op een tamelijk willekeurige manier of in ieder geval niet op de meest efficiënte (in de economische zin) manier: • Onze samenleving zou prima functioneren als slechts 10-20% van de mensen zou werken. De rest van de samenleving (juist de hoogopgeleiden!) kunnen we inzetten voor onzinwerk / overhead. • Mensen noch bedrijven zijn in staat echt rationeel arbeid in te zetten. Om maar wat te noemen: het kán niet efficiënt zijn om de productie van reële goederen (want daar gaat het uiteindelijk om) met zo veel overhead (en dan ook nog eens de duurste arbeiders) in te richten. • Het is dus niet noodzakelijk (zoals vaak door liberalen wordt beweerd) dat iedereen het werk doet waar de samenleving het meest aan heeft  Dit deel van de arbeiders gaat het werk doen waar ze voor is opgeleid (ongeacht of dat nodig is): • Deze willekeurige manier is toch iets minder willekeurig dan je eerst zou denken, want ingericht in het belang / op de vaardigheden van hoogopgeleiden. o Mensen hebben, bewust én onbewust, de neiging om als ze de kans hebben:  Hun eigen vaardigheden belangrijk te vinden  Hun eigen belangen te verdedigen o Hoger opgeleiden zitten vaak (ondanks hun geringe vermogens) in leidinggevende functies. Ze zijn ook vaak degenen die uiteindelijk gaan over de salarisverdeling. • Uiteindelijk leidt dit ook tot belachelijke inefficiëntie: o Ons (hoger-) onderwijsstelsel is primair gericht op het aanleren van schrijven en analytisch denken. We creëren allemaal schrijvers en analytici. Maar hoeveel wetenschappers heeft een samenleving nodig? o Nu vraag je je natuurlijk af: waar besteden al die hogeropgeleiden hun tijd dan aan? Nou, bij voorkeur aan:  Rapportjes (die vaak op geen enkele manier bijdragen aan de efficiëntie / duurzaamheid van de productie).  Lezingen / events / workshops voor elkaar organiseren  Logo’s en nog betere namen ontwikkelen  Reorganiseren

-KlYdxoKQuSxTSXVAysf.content: I’ve never understood why people make such a fuzz over the nature/nurture-question in gender studies – even (actually mostly) exceptionally smart people. More precisely, I don’t see why it has any relevance as an academic debate. I do see why it may, on a very superficial level, an important debate – why it sounds cool and interesting so to say, but I don’t see why any scientist would ever in his right mind present it as more relevant than the debate whether, let’s say, the sky is more blue than a blue violet – not at all that is.

-KlYdxoLEsuVTkglkVHD.content: Let me start by explaining why I think people are attracted to this debate and why I assume people may see it as important. To do that, let’s start with a volcano. Nobody would ever make a normative statement about the eruption of volcanos. You don’t say “that volcano-eruption was illegitimate, or unjust”. Now, it seems attractive to say that that’s the case because volcanos are a natural phenomenon – and we don’t judge natural phenomena the way we judge human behaviour. But that’s too easy. It is the fact that we humans have no control over it that make the normative side non-existent. Imagine that we had full control over all volcanos in the world – by building hypothetical shields above each and every volcano. If opening up the shield would lead to an almost certain and almost immediate eruption, we would start talking about that same eruption as if it was caused by us humans opening it (compare: demolishing a dike and as such restoring the natural position of the water, would be seen as an action and would endow you with guilt, only because we have the ability to stop the flood – the “natural” situation). Concluding: there is no such thing as “objective” causation (because that always introduces the arbitrariness of the choice for a natural or neutral position – and we don’t want our judgements to be based on arbitrary choices). The only question that matters here, is whether we as humans would have had any influence over the outcome.

-KlYdxoLEsuVTkglkVHE.content: Now often, “natural phenomena” are phenomena that we have relatively little control over – and that makes the confusion (natural phenomenon -> natural cause -> can’t judge) so logical. But it’s not always the case, and it’s a dangerous confusion because it can make something often quite arbitrary and always quite irrelevant question of whether something is “natural” suddenly a super important question. But it isn’t.

-KlYdxoMJMpR_nWxPP4m.content: Let me explain by going back to the nurture nature debate. In short, it is intuitively attractive to think that gender differences are in some way problematic if they are the result of cultural norms and social structures (nurture) and are not normatively problematic (so not more than a volcano eruption can be problematic – just a fact of life) if they directly stem from biological factors (nature). But here we are mixing things up. And we can show that from two angles.

-KlYdxoMJMpR_nWxPP4n.content: First, we can wonder what it would mean for something to be “nature”. What do we mean by natural behaviour? Is there a golden standard to separate nature from nurture? No there’s not – it’s deeply arbitrary. It implies that we can think about the absolute “neutral” or “unspoiled” human that has “no culture” whatsoever, but that is impossible. What do we mean by this person? Someone who never encountered someone else and runs naked through the woods? But is that natural? Or would it be the differences we’d encounter if we would let men and women alone in a desert? And would you let them together? Alone? In a group? And what would “unspoiled by culture” mean in a group? Human groups always have culture. And if you find that all groups share the same peace of culture, would you describe that as nature or nurture? And what if one in a thousand groups doesn’t share this single feature? Would that suddenly make it nurture? That all sounds deeply arbitrary.

-KlYdxoMJMpR_nWxPP4o.content: Second, once we have chosen our “neutral” man and woman, we will realize that we were wrong about what we described as “facts of nature” – because there is enough to judge from the beginning. Let’s assume that the men would start raping the woman. Would we than conclude that rape is apparently part of human nature, and as such a fact of life of which we can’t judge? No. We would judge because – and this is the main point – we know that this man has the ability not to rape. It is not the question whether this behaviour is natural that affects (the existence of) our moral judgement, it is the question whether we as humans have the ability to change it.

-KlYdxoNtEY-FvTtNbSB.content: And that brings me back to the main point. The triumph of the conclusion that something is “nurture” seems to be that as a result it has normative implications and the triumph of the conclusion that something is nature seems to be that we have to accept it as a fact of life. Now, there is something to say for the first conclusion if one asserts that we do have some control over our own culture, but there is no basis for the second claim.

-KlYdxoOawwHdX4N6Ya8.content: So, concluding, any “results” in nature nurture-debates cannot have normative implications because (1) that would base our judgements on inherently arbitrary grounds, namely the specific construction and choice of a “natural condition”, and (2) it misses the point that judgements are based on the question whether we can change the state of affairs and whether we have influence over it, not on whether or not a situation is natural (an easy, but also quite obvious, confusion).

-KlYdxodvhiH59-lFHAA.content: Public opinion research has established that xenophobia is often related to authoritarian values. Paradoxically however, the perceived lack of support for and adherence to liberal values among immigrants seems to be playing an increasingly important role in the political and media debate on immigration and integration policies in several Western European countries. At one end of the political spectrum, leaders of Western European anti migrant parties like Pia Kjaersgaard of the Danish Peoples Party and Geert Wilders of the Dutch Freedom Party express strong support for freedom of speech, separation of church and state, and women and gay emancipation movement and at the other end left-wing elites stand increasingly suspicious towards multiculturalist policies, especially where cultural tolerance implies accommodating traditional or religious lifestyles. There is clearly a tension between our traditional knowledge of the factors leading to xenophobic attitudes on the one hand and the fact that in recent cases broad adherence to liberal values appears to be inducing negative attitudes towards migrants. There seems to be a direct connection between the embracement of liberal and non-traditional values in Western Europe on the one hand and the recent emergence of negative attitudes towards migration. The aim of this project is to study the relation between these liberal values and attitudes towards immigrants and immigration in Western European countries.

-KlYdxoesmpq7Nnrbf6G.content: Before moving on to the question how to explain and study this relation, we should first ask ourselves whether what we see is a real paradox. Several scholars have claimed that liberal values and nationalism can go hand in hand, or even that a certain amount of nationalism and ethnocentrism is a necessary precondition for a liberal society (e.g. Lind, 1994; Mason, 1999; D. Miller, 1995) or that the liberal Western society needs to be defended against threats from outside (e.g. Scruton, 2002). However, although it is highly debatable whether this means that cultural intolerance can be justified by reference to the defence of liberal tolerance [ref?], this project is not concerned with the philosophical compatibility of ethical liberal ideals on the one hand and nationalism, ethnocentrism or xenophobia on the other.

-KlYdxofQGuRkMfNQSt2.content: [I might add a short discussion somewhere on the role of liberal values in neo-conservatism and Neo-conservatism as a liberal attitude (Freedman, 2005) and on the restricted nationalism of some explicitly liberal thinkers (David Miller, 2005; Rawls, 1999) and discuss some other classical ways of looking tolerance towards less liberal or illiberal ideas, tolerating the intolerant (Taylor, 1992; Walzer, 1996). Even for some explicitly multiculturalist thinkers there are limits to tolerating the intolerant (Kymlicka, 1995, pp. 152-172).

-KlYdxohTiQY0dIWKvvm.content: The tension under research is not philosophical but rather psychological in nature: it is a broadly established fact that negative attitudes of individuals towards out-groups, and in particular migrants, are seldom accompanied by tolerance towards other groups or adherence to liberal values in general. But although from earlier psychological research we might conclude that it’s highly unlikely for someone to hold strong liberal, non-conservative values and strong negative attitudes towards immigrant groups at the same time, the justifications for “immigration sceptical” (Rydgren, 2008) or xenophobic views in the public debates in many Western European countries are for a large part, and increasingly so, based on the liberal ideals we usually expect to find among the political left and would traditionally not associate with a negative or sceptical attitude toward migrants. Among the wide range of liberal ideals that play a, oftentimes central, role in Western European as justification for immigration scepticism are freedom of expression, separation of church and state, sexual rights and more in particular gay rights (e.g. Mepschen, Duyvendak and Tonkens, 2010) and women rights. Although these justifications differ highly in content and form, the underlying reasoning is usually the same: native inhabitants or members of the ethnic majority, share a common set of (liberal, progressive or emancipatory) values which immigrants, in particular Muslim immigrants, do not share. The perceived traditionalism or “backwardness” of immigrants or immigrant cultures and it’s incompatibility with modern, secular and progressive life in Western Europe is, in these justifications, causing a wide range of problems in the receiving country.

-KlYdxoih1RQ0qCZZuKT.content: [short section on the specific case of the Netherlands]. So how does this liberal value adherence in Western European countries affect the way migration is being discussed and thought about?

-KlYdxojXsN9OFiAdyZ4.content: This project is concerned with the puzzle how the on first sight unlikely coupling of immigration scepticism with liberal ideals emerged and how this coupling has affected public opinion, public debates and politics. In doing so, this research might also help solving the brother puzzle of how and under which conditions migration politics became a highly salient and politicized topic in a large number of Western European countries, of which the electoral success of a number of anti-migrant parties is only one of it’s manifestations.

-KlYdxok9I-CVRApBYTQ.content: As a starting point to understanding this phenomenon, there are two courses we could follow to solve the puzzle formulated above. First we could argue that, contrary to common knowledge, liberal value adherence and negative attitudes towards migrants can go hand in hand, at least under specific conditions. The second approach would be to argue that what we’re observing is not the result of a direct relation between public liberal value adherence and anti-migrant attitudes. The following two sections will be dedicated to the discussion of respectively the first and second approach.

-KlYdxorHTmFO3nA6tbA.content: Approach 1 - liberal values can induce xenophobia: cultural threat

-KlYdxorHTmFO3nA6tbB.content: Although contradicting traditional psychological knowledge, it is possible to build up an argument based on recent social psychological and public opinion research that, under certain conditions, liberal value adherence can indeed induce xenophobia. One of the most consistent findings in recent to both anti migrant attitudes as well as the public debate on immigration in several Western European countries, is that people increasingly think and talk about immigrants and immigration in terms of cultural differences (Entzinger, 2002; Linde-Laursen, 2007; Sniderman & Hagendoorn, 2007; Tonkens, Hurenkamp, & Duyvendak, 2008; Wren, 2001). Additionally, where the perception of “realistic group threats”, most specifically economic threats, used to be the main cause for xenophobic attitudes, these attitudes are now best predicted as a consequence of the perception of symbolic or cultural threats (see also McLaren, 2003; Schneider, 2008; Sears, 1988 on symbolic racism; Sniderman, Hagendoorn, & Prior, 2004; Zárate, Garcia, Garza, & Hitlan, 2004). We might expect that the intensity of this perception of cultural threat is mainly influenced by the perception of a cultural distance between natives and immigrants.

-KlYdxos9bqq4s4276om.content: Arguably, the most obvious explanation for the perception of cultural threat is the existence of real culture differences. In line with the observation that Western European media increasingly discuss migration in terms of cultural differences or cultural clashes between natives and Islamic immigrants, especially since the 9/11 attacks (Hussain, 2000; Roggeband & Vliegenthart, 2007; Sleegers, 2007), one might easily assume that negative attitudes towards migrants are indeed the result of real clashes between cultures (e.g. Sniderman & Hagendoorn, 2007). We should note however that such a relation is not necessarily obvious: strong positive relations between real world indicators that are expected to affect threat perception (migration numbers, crime statistics etc.) have rarely been found in past research , so the relation between real world developments (in this case cultural differences) and the perception of threats might be more complex, a topic that’s more extensively discussed in the next section. However, if we take cultural threat perception serious as an explanation for immigration scepticism, there is enough reason to look for causes in the cultural domain most specifically by looking at cultural differences.

-KlYdxotSjMj8YglP8g_.content: If we do assume that cultural differences are indeed an important factor causing the cultural threat perception which in turn lead to negative attitudes towards migrants, we are getting closer to formulating a reason why liberal value adherence under specific conditions might lead to xenophobic attitudes. This is a consequence of the fact that, although culture and cultural differences can come in many ways, it appears as if a very specific manifestation of cultural differences is driving the opinion on immigration and immigrants in many Western European countries. The background for this particularity has at least as much to do with the specific features of the native populations of these countries as it has with immigrants.

-KlYdxotSjMj8YglP8ga.content: Although there are some differences in extent, European societies, and especially those in Western Europe, are the most secularized (Norris & Inglehart, 2004), most post-materialist (R. Inglehart, 1997), most emancipation-oriented (Welzel, Inglehart, & Kligemann, 2003) and most self expression-oriented (R. Inglehart & Welzel, 2005) societies in the world, most of which they became relatively recently. These cultural characteristics can all be regarded as the precondition for the acceptance of many concrete liberal ethical ideals as freedom of speech, sexual tolerance and women rights and emancipation and Western Europeans are indeed relative strong in supporting these ideals [ref.]. Many European immigrants, on the other hand, come from a relatively traditional background and have strong religious beliefs that are indeed [very distinct] from European natives [ref.]. If we also consider that in several western European countries a public debate has emerged where topics that are related to a multicultural society or immigration are framed in terms of a perceived clash between liberal, “enlightened” values of the indigenous population and traditional, “backward” values of the migrant population, it seems that, if we’re searching for the specific terrain where cultures between European natives and immigrants are clashing, liberal value adherence is the obvious candidate.

-KlYdxouz0A3i44FABj4.content: This brings us to the point where liberal values can cause xenophobic attitudes: under the condition that (1) cultural differences are causing xenophobic attitudes, (2) the most important cultural difference in this respect is the difference in acceptance of certain liberal principles and (3) immigrants are less liberal with regard to these principles than native citizens, liberal value adherence of natives leads, ceteris paribus, to a larger cultural distance and as a consequence more negative attitudes towards migrants. Whether or not condition (2) holds true might partly depend on the value homogeneity amongst natives: the stronger the agreement on these liberal principles, the easier they will become the single most important distinction between natives and immigrants.

-KlYdxouz0A3i44FABj5.content: The idea that exceptionally liberal and tolerant ideas views on life can indeed under specific conditions lead to in general more negative attitudes towards migrants, seems to be confirmed by the Dutch case (Duyvendak, 2004) where debates on the emancipation of women, sexual freedom and freedom of speech appear to be permanently connected to discussion on immigrant integration, especially since the late 1990s and early 2000s when public figures like Ayaan Hirsi Ali and Paul Scheffer introduced this theme. Now it seems as if, even though the embracement of liberal and secular in the Netherlands is a development that took place only several decades ago, the Dutch are no longer able or willing to cope with more traditional or religious approaches to life. For migrants or “allochtones”, the only way to become part of the Dutch nation is by joining the natives on what Van Reekum (2009) calls their liberal plateau with equality only for those who are on it. Similar dynamics might be feeding debates on immigration and immigrant integration in Denmark [ref.].

-KlYdxovsKMaFt5rRujW.content: Still, in spite of these observations, there is enough reason to doubt whether the acceptance of liberal values can really have a stimulating effect on xenophobic attitudes. It is broadly established that xenophobic attitudes are usually related to authoritarian values, (Adorno, 1950; Canetti-Nisim & Pedahzur, 2003; Krange, 2001; e.g. Louis, Duck, Terry, Schuller, & Lalonde, 2007; Scheepers, Felling, & Peters, 1990) , which in turn are negatively associated with liberal values. The idea that values of tolerance and emancipation are positively correlated with positive stances towards migrants is so strongly rooted in social science that oftentimes in academic research they are in analyzed as a single dimension (Kriesi et al., 2008; Middendorp, 1970; Stenner, 2005; Volkens, Lacewell, Regel, Schultze, & Werner, 2009). We might have to look at other ways of explaining liberal xenophobia if we want to give a credible explanation of this phenomenon.

-KlYdxovsKMaFt5rRujX.content: Approach 2 – it’s slightly more complex: arenas, justifications and causes

-KlYdxovsKMaFt5rRujY.content: The second approach to understanding liberal xenophobia would be to conclude that what we’re observing is the result of different processes, potentially not caused by clashing cultures or broad support for liberal values at all. This argument can be made in two ways: by distinguishing political debate, public debate in mass media and public opinion as three separate domains and by distinguishing a causal link between liberal value adherence and xenophobia from the use of liberal justifications for xenophobic attitudes.

-KlYdxow-DLdCSXiuKHt.content: Separation of domains / arena’s of debate

-KlYdxow-DLdCSXiuKHu.content: First we should acknowledge that public opinion and the public debate can be studied in at least three separate, but closely connected, domains: the domain of the individual citizen, the domain of the mass media and the domain of politics. In doing so, we can argue that although liberal principles and xenophobic attitudes can go hand in hand in the domain of politics or the media debate, this doesn’t mean that they are related on the level of individual citizens. Clearly, the observations about the emergence of liberal xenophobia are all made by looking at the public debates mainly driven by politicians and other public figures. On the other hand, the supposed psychological incompatibility of liberalism takes place at the level of the individual citizen.

-KlYdxow-DLdCSXiuKHv.content: By using this approach we can at least partly solve the puzzle as formulated above, although it gives rise to new, closely related puzzles. The question now becomes not so much how liberal values and xenophobic attitudes can go together, but how and under what conditions (citizens level) public opinion and public debate in the media and politics are not in line with each other. As party politics has a dynamic on its own, parties do not necessarily have to take up positions in the political space where real voters are [ref], although the observation of such a phenomenon clearly bags for explanation. In short liberal values and anti-migrant attitudes can be combined at the political level, even though they won’t be at the individual and it is possible that although there are no liberal-xenophobic voters, liberal-xenophobic parties do exist. In a similar way, the (elite-) debate in the media is not necessarily connected to the way ordinary citizens talk and think about the same topics, although the public does to a certain extent pick up media frames and elite positions [ref.].

-KlYdxoxgoKRkUq662_S.content: By separating between the three domains as described above, this project can contribute to the larger body of research that aims at understanding the complex relations between these three domains. E.g. on migration: Walgrave en de Swert ([jaar]), Walgrave ([jaar]), Koopmans and Muis ([jaar]), Boomgaarden en Vliegenthart ([jaar]), Vliegenthart ([jaar]), Green-Peddson (2008) about the relation between Media and Public opinion and / or politics, Rydgren (2003), Lubbers et al. 2002, Van der Brug and Fennema ([jaar]) about the relation between public opinion and politics and electoral behaviour voting. [short discussion of literature]

-KmjThBf4yDl5i23Zsxh.content: The coefficient / effect size should not be reported when test is not significant.

-KmjToSkDxMdrP886BDk.content: Found in many statistics books / introductions to statistics: if you deem the coefficient or effect size a relevant number for significant effects, it is relevant when they are not significant. This may be counter-intuitive, but there is absolutely no reason to value this number differently depending on the outcome of the significance test. Also for a non-significant effect, the value (e.g. coefficient in a regression) is still the best estimate of the effect - 0 is not a better predictor, it's just "also a possible prediction". However, there is uncertainty in any prediction - but this uncertainty is as present in the significant predictor as it is in the significant predictor. To make it more specific: why would it be meaningful to say that the average of a predictor that could range between 0.1 and 2.1 is 1.0, while it is not meaningful to say that the average of a predictor that could range between -0.1 and 1.9 is 0.8. In practice, this approach stimulates the common misunderstanding or intuition that the absence of an effect (effect of 0) is the most likely / meaningful conclusion when a predictor is not significant.

-Kmjjt2EnPpjXC7B6UuK.content: Significance of population parameters => there is no such thing

-Kmjlp_tP4WG6ol7pi3_.content: Common misunderstanding 2: formulating that the effect of something (i.e. the population parameter) is significant. ~Significance is a property of a sample parameter / statistic, not of a population estimate. This leads to the impression that significance actually tells us something about the population - it does not. Real life does not present us with "significant" effects - so we can not conclude that a population effect "is significant". We can merely conclude that our sample descriptor (statistic / parameter) is significant - which implies that our sample descripter is strong enough to conclude that something interesting may be going on in the population.

-KmjmGCe0ure0J7jRKVX.content: So "... is a significant predictor of ..." is wrong and is a symptom of a deep misunderstanding of what we're doing. If anything, it should be "... was a significant predictor of ..." to stress that this is a statement about the found sample that only pertains this specific study, not a statement about reality as it exists outside this study,

We moeten elkaar laten weten dat we onuitgesproken eigenlijk heel goed weten wat we fout doen. En dat het niet meer dan normaal is om daar wat mee te doen. Dat maakt je geen fundamentalist. Ik neem me voor mensen aan te spreken die - vaak onbewust en zelden bedoeld - mensen kwetsen of bijdragen aan het voortbestaan van beelden en taal die ondersteuning biedt aan onderdrukkende structuren en andere vormen van onrecht. Dat betekent dat ik de rol op me zal moeten nemen die me eigenlijk niet zo bevalt: die van de zuurpruim die anderen in verlegenheid brengt. En 4.: ik zal m'n mond niet meer houden. Stap 1 naar een betere wereld is benoemen dat deze wereld niet best is. Dat is makkelijk te doen in die situatie waar je aan de kant staat waar de klappen vallen, maar een behoorlijke stap en enigszins een opoffering (wie wil de verrader zijn?) aan de kant die iets te verliezen heeft. Maar ik geloof niet dat ik de enige ben - en zolang niemand het lef heeft om uit te spreken hoe idioot onze wereld is, komen we nergens.

-KnKcZoxMNmSSUSgeu5O.content: Significance is in itself utterly meaningless in any real life situation. Of course, it is based on (hopefully) meaningful data, so it is often possible to draw a somewhat imprecise and often intuitive interpretation, particularly when a skilled researcher knows that the N is relatively small, but that is no excuse. It is still an active mutilation of meaningful data to become something satisfying - but absolutely meaningless. In no way is this problem solved by also looking at "effect sizes". The "steps" as they are usually taught - i.e. first test for significance, than report effect size when a significant effect is found - is absurd. There is no valid justification for not reporting the effect size when p = 0.06 and reporting it when p = 0.04 - as it is almost as informational and even in the first case, it is the best estimate available (always better than 0).

-KnKdEyMEgtCGDd-l0dw.content: There are barely any cases where a researcher has a substantial interest in the existence of any effect versus no effect. It's absurd to imply that the difference between 0.00001 and 0 is more "significant" than the difference between that same 0.000001 and 100. Of course (and as always), the confusion is entirely understandable. We tend to say "there is a connection", when we mean to say "there is a substantial connection". We can't blame the statisticians that they devised a system that can test the first statement - but we should keep in my mind that in no case (as far as I can think except for borderline cases where we are studying problems of communications - did information travel at all) that first statement is relevant. What we are interested in is substantial effects - not the absolute absence of effects.

Vorig jaar merkten we dat de studenten het college lastiger vonden dan we zelf hadden gedacht, en dat ze het vooral moeilijk vonden om te herkennen waar het besprokene (m.n. de eerste welvaartsstelling) betrekking had op staten. We hebben het vermoeden dat dat heel makkelijk op te lossen is met een heel korte introductie over wat de stelling inhoudt en wat de implicatie is voor de rol van staten voordat het feitelijke bewijs begint. In ieder geval alvast veel dank!

Groet, Elmar

-KnhFd4DDStWPjYN_ylu.content: More specifically, I don't really see why solar energy on chicken farms is something so special that it needs to be studied by scientists. -Kpq4dKmtEw2U5SIia1V.content: Vaak zien we overheidsbeleid als het draaien aan een schakelaar - en dat is natuurlijk niet zo gek. Overheden kunnen aan de knoppen draaien en zo samenlevingen veranderen - bepalen wie wat krijgt, bepalen wie hard moet werken, bepalen wie er in de gevangenis terecht komt. In het kort streeft idealisme naar denkbeeldige overheids-draaiknoppen die zoveel mogelijk richting "uit" gedraaid zijn. De gedachte is logisch - meer dan aantrekkelijk, ook een duidelijke interne rechtvaardigheid: overheden bemoeien zich op grootschalige wijze met ons leven - en dat valt alleen te verantwoorden als het draaien aan die knop ook iedereen beter maakte.

-Kpq5pdnmhECRCZyFnRv.content: Mijn bezwaar tegen liberalisme is niet dit uitgangspunt - ik denk dat het uitgangspunt juist is. Mijn bezwaar is dat het geen zinnig uitgangspunt is, omdat het in geen enkele daadwerkelijke situatie toepasbaar is. Dat zit hem niet in het feit dat overheden niet kunnen draaien, of dat de "uit"-positie - om wat voor reden dan ook - onwenselijk is. De reden is dat er geen "uit"-posities bestaan. Veel liberalen stellen voor in onze alomtegenwoordige staat op een aantal kleine gebieden die knop naar uit te draaien - maar daar is natuurlijk niets inherent rechtvaardigs aan. Je kunt niet roepen dat het tijd is om knopjes naar 0 te draaien, nadat je eerst een enorme structuur, een gigantisch steigerwerk, en een totale controle van de samenleving hebt opgetuigd. Meer specifiek zijn er een aantal terugkerende redenen die maken dat spreken over een neutrale stand eenvoudigweg in de meeste situaties betekenisloos is.

-Kpq7vnkdvirpB1ukDUs.content: Logisch gezien is het helemaal niet zo aannemelijk om uit te gaan van een neutrale positie. Het lijkt echter diep verankerd in ons denken - een verleidelijke denkfout, zogezegd. Dat maakt het interessant om te verkennen hoe die denkfout werkt - met andere woorden, hoe we precies invulling geven aan de "neutrale" positie. Vooral omdat we vaak zo specifiek denken te weten wat de neutrale positie is, lijkt het erop dat we een aantal "heuristieken" gebruiken. De gedachte aan een neutraal punt is eigenlijk altijd een fictie.
